review.title: Improved Knowledge Base Completion by Path-Augmented TransR Model
review.abstract: Knowledge base completion aims to infer new relations from existing information. In this paper, we propose path-augmented TransR (PTransR) model to improve the accuracy of link prediction. In our approach, we base PTransR model on TransR, which is the best one-hop model at present. Then we regularize TransR with information of relation paths. In our experiment, we evaluate PTransR on the task of entity prediction. Experimental results show that PTransR outperforms previous models.

metadata.title: Improved Knowledge Base Completion by Path-Augmented TransR Model

sections.text: In this paper, we propose a path-extended TransR model (PTransR) to improve the accuracy of link prediction. In our approach, we base the PTransR model on TransR, currently the best one-hop model. Subsequently, we regulate TransR with information on relationship paths. In our experiment, we evaluate PTransR based on the task of entity prediction. Experimental results show that PTransR surpasses previous models. Keywords: completion of the knowledge base, relationship path, link prediction.

sections.heading: 2 Our Approach
sections.text: In this section, we present our PTransR model in detail. In Section 2.1, we present the TransE model and explain how TransR overcomes the weakness of TransE. Afterwards, we supplement the TransR model with path information in Section 2.2.

sections.heading: 2.1 Base Model: TransR
sections.text: As stated in Section 1, the embedding of entities and their relationship in vector spaces is effectively an exploitation of internal structures containing a knowledge base, and therefore helpful in predicting missing triplets without using additional texts. The first model in such a research direction is TransE [11]. It embeds entities and their relationship in an equal low-dimensional vector space; the embedding of the two entities is translated by a relation that can be considered an offset vector. In other words, for a tripartite relationship (h, r, t) we want h + r. "(Here, bold letters refer to the embedding of head-tail entities and the relation.) The plausibility of a tripartite relationship (h, r, t) is then evaluated by a scoring function (h, t), in a range h + r."

sections.heading: 2.2 Path-Augmented TransR: PTransR

sections.heading: 2.3 Training Details
sections.text: We train PTransR by mainly following PTransE [14]. Initial vectors and matrices. Following TransR, we obtain initial vectors and matrices for PTransR from TransE. The configuration of TransE is: Margin γ = 1, learning rate α = 0.01, method = unif and epoch = 1000. Negative samples. We sample negative triplets by randomly replacing head or tail entity t or relationship r. For example, (h, r, t) -derived negative triplets (h, r, t), (h, r, t), (h, r, t), (h, r, t), and (h, r, t), where (h, r, t), (h, r, t), (h, r, t), (h, r, t. sections.heading: 3 Evaluation
sections.text: In this section we present the results of our experiment. First we briefly present the data set and the task of the entity prediction, then we show the experimental results and analyze the performance.

sections.heading: 3.1 Dataset
sections.text: FB15k is a commonly used dataset for completing knowledge databases. Table 1 shows statistics of FB15k. FB15k dataset contains factual information in our world, such as location / country / language. Since FB15k has different types of relationships, it is suitable for evaluating PTransR. That is why we choose FB15k as our experimental dataset.

sections.heading: 3.2 Experimental Settings
sections.text: Entity prediction aims to predict the missing entity in an incomplete triplet, i.e. the prediction of h givenr and t or the prediction of t given h and r. Following the settings in TransE, in a triplet (h, r, t) we replace the header unit h with each entity e and calculate the score of (e, r, t). Entity candidates are ranked according to their scores. We repeat the same process to predict the entity t. Then, we use the two metrics in TransE to evaluate the performance: MeanRank (average rank of the expected entity) and Hits @ 10 (percentage of triplets whose head / tail entity is in the top 10 in the ranking). However, there may be several entities plausible for the same incomplete triplet.

sections.heading: 3.3 Overall Performance
sections.text: Table 2 shows the experimental results. If we compare the results of PTransR with the results of previous models, we have the following main observations: (1) PTransR performs significantly better than TransR on each measure, showing that path-enlarged models can achieve better results than one-hop base models. (2) PTransR performs better than PTransE on MeanRank and is comparable to PTransE in Hits @ 10, showing that path-aggregated models with a better one-hop base model can achieve better results. Table 3 shows the performance in the four relation categories 1-to-1, 1-to-n, n-to-1 and n-to-n, with Hits @ 10 (filters) being the measurement. Table 3 shows that PTransR has consistent imports compared to TransR in all four relation categories.

sections.heading: 3.4 In-Depth Analysis and Discussion
sections.text: As shown in Section 1, despite the massive pull rate of FB15k, some relationships cannot be properly captured due to the problem of data sparseness. We divide the relationships into five groups according to their frequency in the pull rate, as shown in Table 4. The mean rank (raw) of TransR and PTransR is compared in Table 4 and the improvement from TransR to PTransR is illustrated. First, we see that PTransR performs better than TransR in all five relationship groups. Second, as the frequency of relations decreases, the improvement increases, which means that path information is useful for dealing with the problem of data sparseness.

sections.heading: 4 Related Work
sections.text: Relationship extraction is an important research topic in the NLP. It can be roughly divided into two categories based on the source of information.Text-based approaches to extracting units and / or relationships from plaintext. For example, Hearst [17] uses "is a | an" pattern to extract hyponymy relations. Banko et al. [6] proposes to extract open domain relationships from the Web. Fully supervised relationship extraction, which divides two marked units into several predefined relationships, has become a hot research arena in recent years [18,19,8].The completion of the knowledge base / population, on the other hand, does not use additional text. Socher et al. [20] suggest a tensor model for predicting missing relationships in an existing knowledge base, which shows the ability of neural networks to draw conclusions from entity relationships. Then, approaches to translating embeddings to complete the knowledge base are proposed [11,12,14].

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we complement the one-hop TransR model with a path modeling method that leads to the PTransR model. We evaluate PTransR by task of predicting entities and compare the performance of PTransR with that of previous models. Experimental results show that path information is useful to solve the problem of data sparseness, and that PTransR surpasses previous models, making PTransR the most advanced model in the area populating the knowledge base without using additional text.

metadata.abstractText: Knowledge base completion aims to infer new relations from existing information. In this paper, we propose path-augmented TransR (PTransR) model to improve the accuracy of link prediction. In our approach, we base PTransR model on TransR, which is the best one-hop model at present. Then we regularize TransR with information of relation paths. In our experiment, we evaluate PTransR on the task of entity prediction. Experimental results show that PTransR outperforms previous models.
